9/ Our job isn't to tell you what you want to hear. Our job is to help you win. Sometimes the most useful advice is the harshest medicine.
8/ Founders also need a dose of reality and a wake up call. Stop being the blind following the blind...
7/ We need a wash out of the old guard and the inexperienced new guard. Better Sherpas will help guide better decisions == better outcomes.
6/ I place immense blame on the lack of real VCs, Angels and incubators b/c very few have any real, useful experience to help guide founders
5/...but it's turning out to be artifacts of success. Leaving a bunch of companies without extra cash on hand and no product/mkt fit...
4/ Somewhere along the way folks in Silicon Valley got confused and thought these things were boundary conditions to success...
3/ Then it was copied by the largest monopoly of humans, time spent and data ever created ($FB)...who also found ways to dilute earnings.
...and who needed costs to dilute their insane profit engine so as to not totally create crazy expectations when eventually public.
1/ Free meals, massages and other perks were started and glorified by a company who created the best business model of all time ($GOOG)...
@Taytus @jdevalk That's a JV. Core biz in US is profitable.
@SCDube @jdevalk Profitable in the US...
@itamarw @eladgil @DanielleMorrill Agreed. Most companies need venture $$$ but none should _need_ venture $$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$!!
@parhaminc to my knowledge only (b) exists right now...
@justinlabel I don't remember that. I was there...
@justinlabel not the point. Point is early profitability vs years of losses.
@jdevalk Uber...
@NowEntrepreneur its a misguided tradeoff...
7/ No excuse for not managing burn, spending on whats crucial and finding a viable business model asap.
6/ Today's CEOs need to internalize this reality and stop falling for the hype cycle of raise $, spend$, fake growth, raise, spend repeat.
5/ But none of these companies relied on ongoing private mkts to fund their expansion or search for profitability.  They found it early on.
4/ $AMZN is another example who takes it to the extreme.  Sinks every profit dollar into expanding their moat.
3/ These companies gush money into all kinds of things.  But their core business was profitable early on and could feed these other bets.
2/ The idea that the path to a massive outcome is massive losses before massive profits is misguided.  People are making up history.

$MSFT IPO in 1986. Profitable since 1982.
$GOOG IPO in 2004. Profitable since 2001.
$FB IPO in 2012. Profitable since 2009.

Trend anyone?

6/ Begs the question, is M&A the only exit? If so, don't expect huge outcomes. Employees will be the worst off - very unfair outcome if so.
5/ Those companies will have a difficult time. Even if they can raise more private money, there isn't a receptive public market for them...
4/ It means startups propped up by venture dollars for unprofitable CAC and negative gross margins to fuel rev growth are DOA...
3/ If these conditions continue to hold, it means public markets are rationalizing growth vs profitable performance.
2/ Positive correlation between revenue growth and EV growth also broke down. Now slightly negatively correlated...
